_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: engine room compressors, ammonia pumps, vessels
_prev_prog_3.Description: The plant has personnel on-site first and second shift to monitor and perform the maintenance on the system.  An alarm system is enabled for all other times when no refrigeration personnel are on-site.  There are security personnel on-site during these off times.  They call one of three or four maintenance staff for responding to equipment faults.  Equipment faults are monitored via a central computer system tied into the equipment?s critical data.  Temperatures, pressures, and levels are some of the data that is monitored.  Automatic shutoff valves are in place and will actuate upon a major fault in the system.  Pressure relief valves are installedon all necessary equipment.  Mechanical Integrity guidelines and procedures are implemented and followed.  All other aspects of the PSM program are implemented and followed.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is to inform all interested persons, including employee?s that Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc, is complying with the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Regulation, Title 29 Code of the Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) Regulations, Title 40 code of the Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68. These Regulations deal with the risk involved with the storage, handling, and processing of hazardous chemicals. In complying this way, we promote overall facility, employee, and public safety. Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence of, and minimize the consequences of, significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall, these programs are in place to prevent the potential for accidental injury, illness, death, and to avoid the potential for property and environmental damage. 

Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc. safety programs are applied to all activities involving hazardous chemicals including use, storage, handling, or the on-site movement of chemicals. Any group of vessels interconnected and separate vessels, which are located such that a hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process. 

Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc. safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and best practices that govern processes, activities, and or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and revised as necessary. All information is communicated to employees of Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc. through training and documentation.

Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc. is a processing and packaging company that utilizes approximately 21,150 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia in its refrigeration systems to cool the facility?s production and shipping area?s.  Expansion in January, 2

006 involved adding a second smaller and independently piped/controlled refrigeration system to the facility.  The specified ammonia estimate of 21,150 pounds includes the inventory from both the old system (System #1) and the newly added system (System #2).  System #2 performs the same fucntions as System #1 (refrigeration of process areas and product) in newly expanded processing/storage areas

A ?Worst Case? and ?Alternative Release? scenario have both been performed and is summarized in Sections 2 and 3, respectively, of the RMP submittal in accordance with post-9/11 EPA policy.  A worst case and alternative release scenario analysis was performed for both the old (System #1) and new (System #2) systems.  The information presented in the RMP submittal is that of the higher impact scenarios (System 1).  

The facility has had one (1) reportable accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in the past five (5) years.  There were no fatalities or injuries as a result of this release.  No on-site or off-site property damage was incurred as a result of the release.  Further details can be obtained in Section 6 of the RMP submittal.

Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc. accidental release prevention programs are based on safe work practices as referenced by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, American National Safety Standards, and the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration  (2 ? 1992). Key elements of this prevention program are comprised of: 

? Equipment design, installation, and operation of Ammonia process systems (ANSI / IIAR 2)?
? Emergency Response and Action Plan Program (OSHA 29CFR1910.120, 1910.38, and EPA 40 CFR Part 68.)?
? Mechanical Integrity, Emergency shutdown procedures, and inspection program (OSHA 29CFR 1910.119).


The facility emergency response program is based on OSHA?s Regulations for Emergency Action Plans (1910.38 and 1910.119) and HAZWOPER (29CFR1910.120). (Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc. ha

s an on-site trained emergency response team (HAZMAT) and maintains a written emergency response plan that is reviewed annually. This plan is coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee, Fire Department, Police and Emergency Medical facilities to ensure communication with all potential or actual involved resources should their involvement be necessitated by a release.)?

Through Process Hazard Analysis, Inspections, annual reviews, and audits, Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc. continuously improves it?s process system, procedures, programs, and training to ensure mitigation, control, technology, equipment, and organizational changes remain consistent and in force. Through this initiative, Golden Crisp Premium Foods, Inc.  can ensure that safeguards are utilized as it relates to its process system and programs for the overall safety and well being of the employees, facility, and the environment.
